item.title: After Over 400 Hours in the Borderlands Franchise, This Is How I intend to Play BL4's Vex First
item.description:
After spending more than 400 hours across Borderlands , Borderlands 2 , Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel , Borderlands 3 , and even Tiny Tina's Wonderlands , it's safe to say the series is a core part of my muscle memory at this point. As it's one of my favorite first-person shooters of all time, I've really been looking forward to getting into Borderlands 4 , especially after getting a small taste of it during a hands-on preview event in June. In fact, it was during that preview that I decided I would be starting my official journey into Borderlands 4 with Vex, the new playable Siren, and a lot of that is due to the way she plays — and her adorable spectral tiger companion, Trouble, of course.

When I first put my hands on the mouse and keyboard and took control of Vex during the hands-on preview event, playing Borderlands 4 was like second nature to me, even with all the new traversal mechanics and Vex's own unique playstyle. This particular Borderlands entry is more difficult than any before it, and yet I found myself constantly urged by the devs behind me to pursue even greater challenges because, according to them, I could "handle it." Some of this boiled down to my experience with Borderlands in general, but it also helped that I had experience with Vault Hunters similar to Vex in the past, giving me a head start on how I would play her when the game finally came out.

I'm Going All In on Vex and Her Minions

Vex's Reaper Minions Should Make Solo Play Much Easier

I'll occasionally be playing Borderlands 4 with friends — there's no doubt about that. However, I know my friends won't always be available when I am, so it's best that I find a way to increase Vex's survivability and viability in solo play. Fortunately, there's no better way to do that than to take advantage of her ability to summon a Reaper Phase Clone Minion in her Dead Ringer tree. Since her Reaper minions taunt enemies and deal melee damage, it'll increase my chances of survival in solo play, and considering how challenging Borderlands 4 is, I'll definitely need it.

I found that playing with FL4K in Borderlands 3 was really beneficial for me as a solo player at the time, thanks to their elemental pet tank that would taunt enemies, and I'm sure Vex's Reaper minions will sufficiently fill that role as well. Plus, I can increase the melee damage, damage reduction, and critical hit damage of Vex's minions via her Phase Familiar tree, making the Reapers even more effective at both taking and dealing damage.

Vex's Specter Minions Will Help With Crowd Control and Damage

What makes Vex even more enticing for solo play is that I can easily summon Specter minions instead of Reapers, which, while they don't move, still act as additional targets but deal more damage. If Reapers are great for Borderlands 4 's boss fights, then surely Specters will be perfect for crowd control. This ability is actually pretty distinct when compared to past Vault Hunters in the series, but the main point is that, knowing how demanding any Borderlands game can be to play solo, not to mention Borderlands 4 , I'll need plenty of backup. Thankfully, Vex's Specter minions provide that.

Now, there's a chance I'll dip more into Vex's Phase Familiar tree, if not just to get to fight alongside Trouble a bit. It's actually the playstyle I chose during the Borderlands 4 hands-on preview I did in June, and I really enjoyed watching the mighty tiger go to work when I summoned him. However, as far as Action Skills go, it looks like Dead Ringer is going to meet my needs more, especially considering its diverse uses.

item.title: New Day One Xbox Game Pass Game Confirmed for November 4
item.description:
Xbox Game Pass subscribers have another day one game they can add to their calendars. As far as day one games go, 2025 may be the all-time best year for Xbox Game Pass, and that's before taking into account the new titles that are on the way in the months ahead.

Earlier this year, Xbox Game Pass subscribers were treated to critically-acclaimed games like Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 and Blue Prince , and most recently, Hollow Knight: Silksong joined the service, earning rave reviews in the process. In fact, Hollow Knight: Silksong reviews have made it the highest-rated game of the year so far. Prior to its release, Clair Obscur was the highest-rated game, and Blue Prince is in the top 10. Clearly, Xbox Game Pass Ultimate subscribers have been getting their money's worth from the day one games, and there's even more to look forward to in the near future.

Football Manager 26 Release Date

  • November 4

While the next few months have yet to be fully fleshed out when it comes to day one Xbox Game Pass games, we do know of some titles that are on the way. And now a new one has been confirmed, with Football Manager 26 confirmed as a day one Xbox Game Pass game when it releases on November 4. For the uninitiated, Football Manager 26 is a soccer management sim, with previous games in the series earning critical acclaim. Starting November 4, Football Manager 26 will be available to PC Game Pass and Game Pass Ultimate subscribers across PC, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X.

Football Manager 26 is the latest game confirmed for Xbox Game Pass in November 2025, but it's not the only one on the horizon for subscribers. It's also been confirmed that Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 is joining Game Pass Ultimate/PC Game Pass on November 14. Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 features a 4-player co-op campaign, round-based Zombies, and of course, the franchise's iconic multiplayer experience.

There are other Xbox Game Pass games to look forward to between now and November. In September, subscribers can look forward to RoadCraft on September 16, Commandos: Origins and Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor on September 17, and Frostpunk 2 on September 18. The Xbox Game Pass October 2025 lineup, meanwhile, is looking especially stacked. Ball x Pit is coming on October 15, while Double Fine's Keeper is joining on October 17. Ninja Gaiden 4 will make its debut as a day one Xbox Game Pass game on October 21, while Bounty Star and Moonlighter 2 are both coming on October 23. Finally, Obsidian Entertainment's The Outer Worlds 2 will be joining Game Pass on October 29. Clearly, the next few months are going to be incredibly busy for Game Pass subscribers.

item.title: I Don't Think I Can Go Back to Hollow Knight After Silksong
item.description:
I absolutely love Hollow Knight: Silksong so far. Team Cherry's sophomore release was well worth the wait in my opinion, taking the best elements of Hollow Knight and remixing them in clever, effective, and nuanced ways. Indeed, Silksong isn't just more of the same; it's a drastic departure from its predecessor in a number of ways, offering a meaningfully distinct gameplay and narrative experience.

Hornet's characterization and the incredible environment design of Pharloom are among my favorite aspects of Silksong , but I would be remiss if I didn't call special attention to what I consider the game's crown jewel: its traversal mechanics. The first Hollow Knight is a pretty great platformer at times, though this is belied by somewhat simplistic, slow-to-develop movement abilities. The Knight's suite of locomotion options is respectable and winds up being rather fun, but movement is also intentionally clunky and unforgiving at times, demanding perfection from players rather than giving them a flexible sandbox to play around in. Hollow Knight: Silksong makes important changes to the platforming pillar of the series' gameplay, and it's making it hard to imagine what going back to the first Hollow Knight might be like.

Hollow Knight: Silksong's Movement Abilities Blow Hollow Knight's Out of the Water

Hollow Knight: Silksong Is Smoother and More Satisfying to Play

I'm sure I've yet to unlock a great deal of Silksong 's movement abilities, but even in the early game, it's clear that Team Cherry is pulling out all the stops. Small features like Hornet's ability to sprint open up new doors for expressive gameplay and technique, and a thoughtfully designed, simple physics engine heightens immersion and allows for greater leaps—literally. Other movement abilities, like the Drifter's Cloak, essentially revolutionize Silksong 's traversal kit in one fell swoop, making both exploration and combat infinitely more enjoyable and multifaceted.

I think that's what has me so giddy about Hollow Knight : Silksong 's gameplay: traversal and combat are intertwined in a way that greatly outshines the first Hollow Knight . Indeed, just about every major upgrade is as much a boon for battling as it is for platforming, lending the gameplay a holistic, interconnected quality. For instance, Hornet's infamous diagonal air strike can be used to deal quick damage against otherwise stalwart foes, but it can also be used to dodge attacks midair, and to bounce off the heads of enemies and specific environment features for swift, acrobatic movement. Similarly, the Drifter's Cloak glide can be used to ride updrafts (of which there are many), close wide gaps between platforms, and avoid damage during fights.

All of this is to say that Silksong 's approach to traversal is so satisfying and bombastic that it makes its predecessor look weak by comparison. Nothing will ever make me call Hollow Knight 's platforming bad, but it feels more like a prototype or proof of concept before Silksong 's movement sandbox. Granted, I'm partial to more acrobatic, fluid locomotion mechanics—it's a big reason why games like Metroid Dread and Bo: Path of the Teal Lotus number among my favorite metroidvanias. Unsurprisingly, Silksong 's gameplay puts it squarely alongside those favorites as well.

Silksong also doles out essential movement upgrades at a faster pace than Hollow Knight , putting its best foot forward, as it were.

The first Hollow Knight is a once-in-a-generation sort of game, a humble indie project that soared against the odds. Hollow Knight: Silksong is coming from the same small team, made with the same earnest intentions, but it's clear that Team Cherry wasn't content to rest on its laurels. It's rare for such a highly anticipated game to live up to expectations, but with incredible movement, tightly design combat, and myriad other highlights, Silksong has done exactly that.

Become the Princess Knight

As the lethal hunter Hornet, adventure through a kingdom ruled by silk and song! Captured and taken to this unfamiliar world, prepare to battle mighty foes and solve ancient mysteries as you ascend on a deadly pilgrimage to the kingdom’s peak.


Hollow Knight: Silksong is the epic sequel to Hollow Knight, the award winning action-adventure. Journey to all-new lands, discover new powers, battle vast hordes of bugs and beasts and uncover secrets tied to your nature and your past.

item.title: Alchemist’s Assistant Quest in Silksong (Plasmium Locations)
item.description:
Alchemist’s Assistant is a side quest in Hollow Knight: Silksong that can be triggered by talking to Alchemist Zylotol in the Wormways. Upon talking to Hornet, Zylotol will reveal that he is looking to collect some Plasmium from the nearby area in the name of scientific research, and will initiate the quest if players show interest.

After giving the quest, the Alchemist does not give the exact locations of where the Plasmium can be found, leaving it for the players to figure out. While Wormways isn’t the largest of areas, its winding tunnels make it very easy to get lost while exploring. This guide covers all three Plasmium locations required to complete Zylotol’s wish, as well as how to collect them.

How to Get Plasmium in Silksong (Alchemist’s Assistant Quest)

To gather Plasmium, you will first need to equip the Needle Phial in your Tools slot by sitting on a bench (there’s one right next to Alchemist Zylotol). Once you have the Needle Phial equipped, you can extract the Plasmium nodes in the Wormways.

There are three Plasmium buds scattered throughout the Wormways that you are required to gather in order to complete the Alchemist's Assistant Wish in Silksong . Here are all their locations:

First Plasmium Location

The first Plasmium Phial is located in an alcove directly underneath Alchemist Zylotol’s location .

  1. Use the exit to the right of the Alchemist to drop down into the level below.
  2. Turn left and use Wall Climb above the spike pit to reach the platform above.
  3. Go left to drop down again, and you’ll see the blue glow of a Plasmium node in the alcove to the right.

Press and hold the Tool activation hotkey to use the Needle Phial to extract the Plasmium.

Second Plasmium Location

The second Plasmium is located further down into the bowels of the Wormways.

  1. From the first Plasmium node, turn left and drop down to the platform below.
  2. Jump left and take the drop leading down to the level below.
  3. Drop down to the platform on the left, then head right to take another hole leading even further down.
  4. Go right to drop down again, then turn left for another drop with a spike pit at the bottom.
  5. Drop down to the right and you’ll find a moss-covered tunnel leading to the second Plasmium node.

Third Plasmium Location

The Third Plasmium node can be found in a hidden section of the Wormways west of the second node’s location.

  1. From the second Plasmium’s location, turn left and use Wall Climb to return the way you came.
  2. To the left of the first falling sandworm is a spike pit, and a wall you can use Wall Climb on to get to the other side. Do so.
  3. Jump across the gap on the left and keep heading left until you see another drop.
  4. Drop down and turn left mid-fall to find an alcove with a breakable stone wall .
  5. Break the wall, and follow the tunnel to the left to find the third Plasmium node .

Alchemist’s Assistant Quest Rewards in Silksong

After collecting all three Plasmium vials, return to Alchemist Zylotol to turn in the quest. As a reward, he will give you a Plasmium Phial , a Tool that allows Hornet to temporarily increase her base health pool by three extra masks , which is extremely useful in boss fights.

The Plasmium Phial comes with 3 active charges , with 20 more in reserve . At most, you can use the Phial to receive 3 temporary masks. When you rest at a bench, Hornet will automatically refill the active charges using the ones in reserve, consuming Shell Shards in the process. Alchemist Zylotol will refill your Plasmium Phial’s reserve charges for a flat fee of 50 Rosaries , regardless of how many are missing.

item.title: All Bilewater Bench Locations in Silksong
item.description:
There are four benches in Hollow Knight: Silksong 's Bilewater area. While players are likely to run into at least one of those benches while exploring Bilewater, some of them are quite well hidden. This guide is here to provide more details on the hidden benches' locations, and it will help players find every bench in Silksong 's Bilewater.

Players will need to unlock double jump in Silksong before they can reach Bilewater's third and fourth benches. This is also a requirement for unlocking the area's map.

Where to Find All Bilewater Benches in Silksong

Bilewater Bench #1

The first bench in Bilewater is in the room with the area's Bell Beast station . As players start exploring Bilewater, they will encounter signs that lead them directly to this room. That said, if a player is struggling to find Bilewater's first bench, they can follow the route shown in the following video, which starts at the entrance to the area.

Bilewater Bench #2

Exit the room with the first bench and go left to find a breakable wall . Beyond that wall, players will find the Mist, and there is a structure that they can enter at the end of that area. This structure is the Exhaust Organ , and players should go up and to the left once inside to activate a bench.

Players need to have access to Needolin in order to reach the Exhaust Organ, and this guide to traversing the Mist in Silksong fully details the process.

Bilewater Bench #3

It is highly recommended that players obtain the Bilewater map on their way to third bench, as it will make finding it much easier. This guide to unlocking the Bilewater map in Silksong explains how that is done, and as previously mentioned, double jump is required to access it.

Bilewater's third bench is hidden near the top of the area. To reach it, players must smash through a breakable wall at the position marked on the preceding map, and the following video demonstrates the full route.

As players climb to the third bench, they may encounter signs pointing them toward a bench. However, the bench that these signs point to is actually a trap , and players who try to use it will quickly find themselves falling into an infectious pool.

Bilewater Bench #4

Silksong players will gain access to Bilewater's final bench upon beating Groal the Great , the boss at the top of the area.
